title: Condensed type for packaging
content:
\<font class="dontLookLikeCrap"\>Need some suggestions about condensed sanserif type that is legible at points (5,6 pt) for packaging.   
(Vitamin drink)   
I was thinking something along the line of DinCon but more legible at smaller sizes.   
   
Ps. It will be set in uppercase fopr the most part   
   
Thanks.\</font\>

 [‹ Font suggestions for children's book](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103083936/http:/www.typophile.com/node/10148 "Go to previous forum topic") [Arial OTF and Arial TT in InDesign HELP!!! ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103083936/http:/www.typophile.com/node/10189 "Go to next forum topic")
author: mrfsrf

comments.content:
If you have a choice I'd strongly recommend against an all-caps   
setting. It will be more readable with lc and you'll save a ton of   
space too.

I agree with Stephen   
   
If legibility is imprtant, [Bell Centennial](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103083936/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/bell-centennial/address/testdrive.html?s=type+that+is+legible+at+points+%285%2C6+pt%29+for+packaging.+&p=24) might do the trick for you.

Some of my favorite readable condensed with large x-heights:   
   
 [Corpid Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103083936/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FK.114378.0.0)   
 [Versa Sans Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103083936/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&font_categories=1&font_categories_search=font_name_search&searchstr=versa+sans+condensed)   
 [FF Strada Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103083936/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FF.11319.0.0)   
 [FF Dax Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103083936/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FF.10001.0.0)   
 [FF Meta Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103083936/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FF.11052.0.0)

Nice suggestions, Stephen.   
   
Hoefler&Frere-Jones's Gotham Condensed has a large x-height too.
